record_data.record_plain_text: Execution Version LGIA CO-TENANCY AGREEMENT by and among IMPERIAL VALLEY SOLAR 1, LLC, IMPERIAL VALLEY SOLAR 2, LLC, IMPERIAL VALLEY SOLAR 3, LLC, IMPERIAL VALLEY SOLAR 4, LLC and IMPERIAL VALLEY SOLAR, LLC, dated as of September 13, 2012 ARTICLE I ARTICLE I DEFINITIONS 2 1.1 Certain Definitions 2 ARTICLE II CO-TENANCY RIGHTS AND OBLIGATIONS 6 2.1 Use of LGIA 6 2.2 Maximum Capacity 6 2.3 Curtailment 6 2.4 LGIA Third Party Expenses 7 2.5 Liquidated Damages; Credits; Refunds 8 2.6 Joint and Several Liability 8 2.7 Capacity 8 2.8 Indemnity 8 2.9 Taxes 9 2.10 Operation and Management: Insurance 9 2.11 Events of Default; Default 10 2.12 Remedies 10 2.13 Disconnection 11 2.14 Equitable Relief 11 2.15 Dispute Resolution 11 2.16 Effect of Force Majeure 12 2.17 Notice of Default 13 2.18 No Interference 13 ARTICLE III MANAGER 13 3.1 Appointment of Manager; Manager Services and Limitations 13 3.2 Communications 14 3.3 Liability and Indemnification of Manager 15 3.4 Books and Records; Reporting Requirements 15 3.5 Replacement of Manager 16 3.6 Management Fee 16 3.7 Discrimination 16 3.8 Performance 16 3.9 Access Rights 17 3.10 Subcontracting 17 ARTICLE IV TRANSFERABILITY 17 4.1 General Restriction and Obligation 17 4.2 Co-Tenant’ s Right to Encumber 17 4.3 Certain Rights of Financing Party 17 4.4 FERC Approval 18 ARTICLE V MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 18 5.1 Notices 18 5.2 Choice of Law 19 5.3 Entire Agreement 19 5.4 Interpretation 19 5.5 Waiver 20 5.6 Third Party Beneficiaries 20 5.7 Counterparts; Facsimile Signatures 20 5.8 Amendments; Term 20 5.9 Acknowledgement and Further Assurances 20 5.10 WAIVER OF RIGHT TO PARTITION 20 5.11 Consequential Damages 21 5.12 Co-Tenant Representative 21 5.13 Manager Representative 21 EXHIBIT A MAXIMUM CAPACITIES EXHIBIT B MINIMUM INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS FOR CO-TENANTS EXHIBIT C MINIMUM INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS FOR MANAGER LGIA CO-TENANCY AGREEMENT This LGIA CO-TENANCY AGREEMENT (this “Agreement”) is made and entered into as of September 13, 2012 (the “Effective Date”), by and among Imperial Valley Solar I, LLC, a Delaware limited liability company (“IVS-1”), Imperial Valley Solar 2, LLC, a Delaware limited liability company (“IVS-2”), Imperial Valley Solar 3, LLC, a Delaware limited liability company (“IVS-3”), Imperial Valley Solar 4, LLC, a Delaware limited liability company (“IVS-4” and, together with IVS-I, TVS-2 and IVS-3, each individually a “Co-Tenant” and collectively the “Co-Tenants”), and Imperial Valley Solar, LLC (the “Manager”). Each of the Co-Tenants and the Manager may also sometimes be referred to in this Agreement as a “Party” and collectively as the “Parties”. RECITALS A. The Co-Tenants are developing and will construct, own and operate a solar energy project with a maximum aggregate capacity of 600 MW (collectively, the “Project”) located in the unincorporated area of Imperial County, California on properties located approximately twelve miles southeast of the SDGandE Imperial Valley Substation. B. Each Co-Tenant will construct, own and operate a separate and disc rete number of photovoltaic panels, current inverters and other assets (each, a “Phase”) of the Project, all of which collectively will comprise the Project. C. The Phases to be constructed, owned and operated by each of IVS-I, IVS-2, IVS-3 and IVS-4 are projected to have a net nameplate capacity of 200 MW, 150 MW, 150 MW and 100 MW, respectively. D. The Co-Tenants, as tenants-in-common, and Manager, as the manager on behalf of the Co-Tenants, have entered into that certain Assignment Agreement, dated as of June 12, 2012, and that certain First Amendment to the Standard Large Generator Interconnection Agreement by and among Manager, Co-Tenants, San Diego Gas and Electric Company (“SDGandE”) and the California Independent System Operator Corporation (the “CAISO”), dated as of June 28, 2012 (the “LGIA Amendment”), with respect to that certain Standard Large Generator Interconnection Agreement by and among Manager (as successor to SES Solar Two, LLC), SDGandE and the CAISO, dated as of August 5, 2009, together with all agreements, schedules, appendices, exhibits and other documents ancillary thereto (all as amended by the LGIA Amendment and as may be further amended or supplemented, the “ LGIA”) for the purpose of securing interconnection rights for the Project and each of the Phases. E. The Parties desire to enter into this Agreement to set forth the terms and conditions under which the Co-Tenants will be co-tenants under the LGIA and share the LGIA among the Co-Tenants and Phases, the Manager shall act as the Co-Tenants’ manager to administer and manage the LGIA on behalf of the Co-Tenants in relation to the CAISO and SDGandE, and certain other related matters. NOW, THEREFORE, in consideration of the foregoing and the agreements and covenants contained herein, and other good and valuable consideration, the receipt and sufficiency of which are hereby acknowledged, the Parties hereto agree as follows: AGREEMENT ARTICLE I ARTICLE I DEFINITIONS 1.1 Certain Definitions. Capitalized words and phrases used herein shall have the following meanings, or the meanings given in the Sections of this Agreement in which they are defined, unless the text expressly or by necessary implication requires otherwise. (a) “Agreement” has the meaning given in the preamble to this Agreement, and includes all exhibits and appendices hereto. (b) “Applicable Laws and Regulations” has the meaning given in the LGIA. (c) “Arbitration Rules” has the meaning given forth in Section 2.15(b). (d) “CATSO” has the meaning given in the recitals to this Agreement. (e) “Capacity” means, in respect of any Phase, the maximum capacity identified and described in Section C.1 of Appendix C to the LGIA, and summarized for each of the Phases in Exhibit A, which number may be changed only in accordance with Section 2.7. (f) “Claims” has the meaning given in Section 2.8(a). (g) “Co-Tenant” and “Co-Tenants” have the meanings given in the preamble to this Agreement. (h) “Co-Tenant Representative” has the meaning given in Section 5.12. (i) “Curtailed Output Cap” has the meaning given in Section 2.3(c)(ii). (j) “Dispute” has the meaning given in Section 2.15(a). (k) “Distribution Upgrades” has the meaning given in the LGIA. (l) “Effective Date” has the meaning given in the preamble to this Agreement. (m) “Emergency Condition” has the meaning given in the LGIA. (n) “Events of Default” has the meaning given in Section 2.11. (o) ““FERC” means the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission or any successor agency. (p) “Financing Party” means any and all lenders (including, without limitation, the U.S. Department of Energy, as a loan guarantor) providing senior or subordinated construction, interim or long-term debt financing or refinancing (including hedging counterparties) for the development, construction, purchase or operation of a Phase and any trustee or agent acting on behalf of any such lenders. (q) “Force Majeure” has the meaning given in the LGIA. (r) “FPA” has the meaning given in Section 2.10(a). (s) “General Default Cure Period” has the meaning given in Section 2.11. (t) “Good Utility Practice” has the meaning given in the LGIA. (u) “Indemnified Co-Tenant” has the meaning given in Section 2.8(a). (v) “Indemnifying Co-Tenant” has the meaning given in Section 2.8(a). (w) “Initial Construction Costs” means all costs incurred and amounts payable by the Interconnection Customer under the LGIA in connection with the initial design, engineering and construction of the Interconnection Customer’s Interconnection Facilities, the Participating TO’s Interconnection Facilities, the Network Upgrades and the Distribution Upgrades (if any ), but excludes any costs incurred or payable following and not related to such initial design engineering and construction (including any costs for the subsequent repair, replacement or maintenance of such facilities and upgrades). (x) “Interconnection Customer” has the meaning given in the LGIA. (y) “Interconnection Customer’s Interconnection Facilities” has the meaning given in the LGIA. (z) “Interconnection Facilities” has the mean given in the LGIA. (aa) “Interest Rate “ means the lesser of (a) the prime rate as published in “The Money Rates” Section of The Wall Street Journal (U.S. Edition), plus four percent (4.00%) per annum and (b) the highest rate permitted under Applicable Laws and Regulations. (bb) “IVS-1” has the meaning given in the preamble to this Agreement. (cc) “JVS-2” has the meaning given in the preamble to this Agreement. (dd) “IVS-3” has the meaning given in the preamble to this Agreement. (ee) “JYS-4” has the meaning given in the preamble to this Agreement. (ff) “LGIA” has the meaning given in the recitals to this Agreement. (gg) “LGIA Amendment” has the meaning given in the recitals to this Agreement. (hh) “LGIA Costs and Operating Expenses” means (i) all amounts due and payable under the LGIA to the CAISO or the Participating TO, (ii) all costs and expenses necessary or appropriate for the Manager to incur or pay in connection with administering and managing the LGIA, including in connection with affirmative covenants with respect to maintenance of the Project and the Interconnection Customer’s Interconnection Facilities, communications with CAISO, insurance and reporting, and SDGandE charges related to the operation and maintenance of the Participating TO’s Interconnection Facilities and (iii) the Management Fee; but excluding the Initial Construction Costs. (ii) “Management Fee” has the meaning given in Section 3.6. (jj) “Manager” has the meaning given in the preamble to this Agreement. (kk) “Manager Representative” has the meaning given in Section 5.13. (ll) “MW” means a megawatt or megawatts AC, as the context may require. (mm) “NERC” means the North American Electric Reliability Corporation or its successor organization. (nn) “Network Upgrades” has the meaning given in the LGIA. (oo) “Notice of Dispute” has the meaning given in Section 2.15(a). (pp) “Participating TO” has the meaning given in the LGIA. (qq) “Participating TO’s Interconnection Facilities” has the meaning given in the LGIA. (rr) “Party” and “Parties” have the meanings given in the preamble to this Agreement. (ss) “Payment Default Cure Period” has the meaning given in Section 2.11. (tt) “Percentage Interest” means, with respect to each Co-Tenant, as of any date of determination, the ratio (expressed as a percentage) of (X) divided by (Y), where (X) equals the Capacity of the Co-Tenant’s Phase, provided that (X) equals zero (0) if such Co­ Tenant’s Phase has not (in part or in full) initially synchronized with the CAISO grid; and (Y) equals the sum of the Capacities in respect of all Phases which have (in part or in full) initially synchronized with the CAISO grid. (uu) “Person” means any individual or entity, and the heirs, personal representatives, successors and assigns of such individual or entity where the context so permits. (vv) “Phase “ has the meaning given in the recitals to this Agreement. (ww) “Phase 1” means the solar energy electric generating facility to be developed, owned and operated by IVS-1 (or its successor or permitted assign) located in the unincorporated area of Imperial County, California on properties located approximately twelve miles southeast of the SDGandE Imperial Valley Substation with a maximum Capacity as set forth on Exhibit A. (xx) “Phase 2” means the solar energy electric generating facility to be developed, owned and operated by IVS-2 (or its successor or permitted assign) located in the unincorporated area of Imperial County, California on properties located approximately twelve miles southeast of the SDGandE Imperial Valley Substation, with a maximum Capacity as set forth on Exhibit A. (yy) “Phase 3” means the solar energy electric generating facility to be developed, owned and operated by IVS-3 (or its successor or permitted assign) located in the unincorporated area of Imperial County, California on properties located approximately twelve miles southeast of the SDGandE Imperial Valley Substation, with a maximum Capacity as set forth on Exhibit A. (zz) “Phase 4” means the solar energy electric generating facility to be developed, owned and operated by IVS-4 (or its successor or permitted assign) located in the unincorporated area of Imperial County, California on properties located approximately twelve miles southeast of the SDGandE Imperial Valley Substation California, with a maximum Capacity as set forth on Exhibit A. (aaa) “Phase Controlled Assets” means, for each Co-Tenant, any of the assets comprising its respective Phase, the corresponding Phase Real Property and related Phase agreements and contractual arrangements. For the avoidance of doubt, the Phase Controlled Assets shall exclude the LGIA. (bbb) “Phase Real Property” means, for any Phase, the real property interests utilized by such Phase. (ccc) “Point of Interconnection” has the meaning given in the LGIA. (ddd) “Project” has the meaning given in the recitals to this Agreement. (eee) “SDGandE” has the meaning given in the recitals to this Agreement. (fff) “Shortfall” has the meaning given in Section 2.3(c)(ii). (ggg) “Transfer” means, with respect to any asset, the sale, assignment, transfer, pledge, encumbrance, transfer, or other disposition, either voluntarily, by operation of law or otherwise, of such asset. “Transferee” shall be interpreted accordingly. (hhh) “Undivided Interest” has the meaning given in Section 2.1. ARTICLE II CO-TENANCY RIGHTS AND OBLIGATIONS 2.1 Use of LGIA. The LGIA shall be held and used solely to permit the interconnection of electricity generated by or on behalf of a Phase owned by a Co-Tenant (or by such Co-Tenant’s successors or permitted assigns) at the Point of Interconnection. Each Co­Tenant shall have an undivided ownership interest (each, an “Undivided Interest”) as tenant-in­common in the rights and obligations of the Interconnection Customer and the LGIA, and possess an undivided right to enjoy all of such Undivided Interest, all in accordance with the terms and conditions hereof. 2.2 Maximum Capacity. No Co-Tenant shall interconnect its respective Phase to the Point of Interconnection to the extent the installed capacity of such Phase exceeds its Capacity. To the extent that conditions exist which result in a Co-Tenant delivering energy to the Point of Interconnection from its respective Phase in excess of the Capacity in respect of such Phase, then such Co-Tenant shall at its expense immediately curtail the operation of its Phase so as not to exceed its Capacity. 2.3 Curtailment. (a) The Manager may, in accordance with this Section 2.3, direct the Co-Tenants to interrupt or reduce deliveries of electrical power (i) when necessary in order to maintain, repair, replace, remove, investigate, inspect or test any part of any Phase; (ii) if the Manager determines, in its reasonable discretion, that interruption or reduction is necessary due to an Emergency Condition; or (iii) at the direction of the Participating TO or the CAISO pursuant to rights under the LGIA. (b) With respect to any interruption or reduction of deliveries of electrical power pursuant to clauses (i) or (ii) of Section 2.3(a), the Manager shall limit the length of any such interruption or curtailment to that time strictly necessary to correct the problem. Any interruption or curtailment made pursuant to clause (i) of Section 2.3 shall be made to the extent commercially reasonable during periods of low or no solar generation or low energy prices. (c) In the event of any curtailment of interconnection services at the direction of CAISO or Participating TO, such curtailment shall be allocated in the following manner until such curtailment is achieved: (i) first, each Co-Tenant (if any) who is delivering energy in excess of such Co-Tenant’s Capacity shall reduce deliveries clown to such Co-Tenant’s Capacity, and (ii) second, each Co-Tenant shall reduce its energy deliveries so that they do not exceed an amount equal to (X) minus (Y) (for each Co-Tenant, such amount, in MW, being referred to as the “Curtailed Output Cap”); where (X) equals such Co-Tenant’s Capacity, and (Y) equals the product of (A) and (B); and where (A) equals the aggregate number of MW then required for the Project to curtail (after application of preceding clause (i)) and (B) equals such Co-Tenant’s Percentage Interest; provided that if during any relevant period of curtailment any Co-Tenant is delivering energy at a level less than its Curtailed Output Cap (any such amount, a “Shortfall”) either because such Co-Tenant’s Phase is undergoing maintenance, has a forced outage, or other circumstance, then for so long as such Shortfall exists, the Manager shall use reasonable efforts to authorize each other Co-Tenant to generate above such Co-Tenant’s Curtailed Output Cap by al locating among such other Co-Tenants the Shortfall on a pro-rata basis in accordance with such other Co-Tenant’s Percentage Interests. (d) Notwithstanding the other provisions of this Section 2.3: (i) The Manager shall be authorized to curtail on a non-pro rata, but equitable and reasonable basis (as determined by the Manager in good faith) if (a) in spite of the Manager’s good faith efforts to direct the Co-Tenants to comply with this Section 2.3, curtailment of interconnection services directed by the CAISO or Participating TO is not otherwise achievable, or (b) such non-pro rata allocation is otherwise necessary to comply with the LGIA or CAISO or Participating TO direction, and, in each of the foregoing cases (a) and (b), that such non-pro rata allocation will not result in a default under the LGIA; and (ii) To the extent that the need for any interruption or reduction can be attributed to a particular Co-Tenant’s Phase or portions of its Phase or the failure of such Phase to comply with the order to curtail or a default by such Co-Tenant under the LGIA or an applicable power purchase agreement, or to the extent such Co-Tenant’s Phase is the cause of an Emergency Condition, then all such curtailment shall be allocated to such Co-Tenant and such Co-Tenant will be responsible for all costs, liabilities, and damages resulting from such curtailment (subject to the limitations in this Agreement) and the Manager shall, to the extent possible, limit such interruption or reduction to such Phase or such portions of the Phase, as the case may be. (e) Each Co-Tenant shall promptly effect such interruption in, or reduction of, delivery as the Manager shall direct pursuant to this Section 2.3 upon notice from the Manager. In the event notice is impracticable or a Co-Tenant fails to promptly comply therewith, the Manager may effect the same by direct action. 2.4 LGIA Third Party Expenses. Each Co-Tenant hereby confirms its obligation to share in the payment of all expenses incurred in connection with the LGIA in accordance with the following provisions: (a) Initial Construction Costs. As among the Co-Tenants, IVS-1 agrees to fund and pay all Initial Construction Costs, and no other Co-Tenant will have any liability or responsibility (including any responsibility to reimburse or compensate IVS-1) in respect of any of the Initial Construction Costs; provided that the foregoing shall not in any way limit any Co­ Tenant’s joint and several liability under Section C.7.2(b)(i) of LGIA Appendix C. As among the Co-Tenants, any refund of any portion of the Initial Construction Costs shall be payable to IVS-1. (b) LGIA Costs and Operating Expenses. Each Co-Tenant shall be responsible for the payment of its pro rata share of the LG IA Costs and Operating Expenses in proportion to such Co-Tenant’s Percentage Interest. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein, any capital expenditures arising out of any upgrades or facilities required to interconnect any particular Phase (other than any and all Initial Construction Costs) shall be for the sole account of such Phase and its Co-Tenant. (c) Collection and Payment of LGIA Costs and Operating Expenses. The Manager shall, as authorized representative for each Co-Tenant, administer the collection, payment and reimbursement of the LGIA Costs and Operating Expenses and other amounts due from the Interconnection Customer under or in connection with the LGIA. The Manager shall be responsible for invoicing the Co-Tenants their respective pro rata shares of such LGIA Costs and Operating Expenses and providing backup documentation for such invoices. The Manager shall establish procedures for invoicing and collecting payments from Co-Tenants in order to enable Manager and Co-Tenants to achieve the payment requirements under and in connection with the LGIA. Each Co-Tenant shall have the right to audit, and receive periodic supporting documentation for, any expenses or other amounts required to be paid by such Co-Tenant hereunder. 2.5 Liquidated Damages; Credits; Refunds. To the extent that the Manager receives any damages, credits or refunds pursuant to the LGIA, the Manager shall promptly remit such damages, credits or refunds to the Co-Tenants according to each Co-Tenant’s Percentage Interest (unless such damages, credits or refunds accrue to a specific Co-Tenant, in which event the Manager shall promptly remit them to such Co-Tenant). 2.6 Joint and Several Liability. Notwithstanding any other provision hereof, each Co-Tenant acknowledges and agrees that under the LGIA it is jointly and severally liable for (i) any payments due under the LGIA imposed on the Interconnection Customer and (ii) the performance of the obligations and duties imposed on the Interconnection Customer by the LGIA; provided that a Co-Tenant’s joint and several liability under the LGIA shall not diminish or impair any Co-Tenant’s rights to reimbursement or contribution from another Co-Tenant hereunder in respect of obligations of another Co-Tenant. 2.7 Capacity. (a) The Capacity with respect to any Phase shall be increased only upon receipt by such Phase’s Co-Tenant of written consent to such increase provided by all of the other Parties, the CATSO and the Participating TO, such consent to be provided in each such party’s sole discretion. (b) The Capacity with respect to any Phase shall be decreased only upon receipt by such Phase’s Co-Tenant of written consent to such decrease provided by (i) the CAISO and the Participating TO, such consent to be provided in each such party’s sole discretion, and (ii) the other Parties, such consent not to be unreasonably withheld (it being acknowledged and agreed that it would be unreasonable for a Party to withhold such consent solely because such decrease would result in a change in such withholding Party’s Percentage Interest). 2.8 Indemnity. (a) Subject to the limitations provided in Section 5.11, each Co-Tenant (an “Indemnifying Co-Tenant”) shall indemnify, defend and hold harmless the other Co-Tenants (each, an “Indemnified Co-Tenant”) and the Manager from and against any and all losses, damages, liabilities, claims, judgments, liens, penalties, costs and expenses, including, without limitation, reasonable attorneys’ and consultants’ fees (collectively, “Claims”), which may be (i) imposed upon or incurred by such Indemnified Co-Tenant or Manager or asserted against such Indemnified Co-Tenant or Manager as a result of any breach by the Indemnifying Co-Tenant of this Agreement or the LGIA, or (ii) incurred by third parties in respect of loss of, or damage to, property or injury to, or death of, persons, as a result of negligence, fraud or willful misconduct of the Indemnifying Co-Tenant. (b) Subject to the limitations provided in Sections 3.3(c) and 5.11, the Manager shall indemnify, defend, and hold harmless the Co-Tenants from any Claims which may be (i) imposed upon or incurred by such Co-Tenants as a result of fraud, willful misconduct or gross negligence of the Manager, or (ii) incurred by third parties in respect of loss of, or damage to, property or injury to, or death of, person s, as a result of negligence, fraud or willful misconduct of the Manager. 2.9 Taxes. Each Co-Tenant shall pay all real and personal property taxes and assessments, general or special, levied against its Phase, except for any taxes or assessments that are LGIA Costs and Operating Expenses. All such taxes and assessments shall be paid before delinquency and before any fine, interest or penalty shall become due or be imposed for their non-payment; provided if a Co-Tenant in good faith contests or disputes such taxes or assessments and furnishes to the other Co-Tenants a bond or other acceptable security in an amount sufficient to discharge all such contested taxes or assessments, such Co-Tenant will not be in default under this Section 2.9 for failing to timely pay such contested taxes or assessments. 2.10 Operation and Management: Insurance. (a) Each Co-Tenant shall operate and maintain its Phase Controlled Assets acting as a prudent operator and manager and otherwise (a) in accordance with the terms of the LGIA, (b) in accordance with Good Utility Practice, (c) in compliance with all Applicable Laws and Regulations, including but not limited to the Federal Power Act, as amended (“ FPA”), and all rules, regulations, and orders issued by the FERC pursuant to the FPA, (d) in compliance with the CAISO Tariff, including the rules, protocols, procedures and standards attached thereto, as the same may be amended from time to time and approved by FERC, (e) in compliance with the rules, protocols, procedures and standards of NERC and WECC, and (f) without causing a material adverse effect on the LGIA. (b) Each Co-Tenant shall comply with its obligations under the LGIA, including with respect to its obligations to fund LGIA Costs and Operating Expenses. Each Co­Tenant shall obtain and maintain status as an “exempt wholesale generator” or a “qualifying facility” as such terms are defined, respectively, in the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 2005 and the FPA. (c) Each Co-Tenant shall cooperate with and timely respond to Manager as a representative for the Co-Tenants under the LGIA, and shall provide Manager such information required by Manager to comply with its obligations under the LGIA. (d) Each Co-Tenant shall maintain insurance in accordance with the requirements of the LGIA (including Section 18.3 of the LGIA) and Exhibit B hereto. The Manager shall maintain insurance in accordance with the requirements of Exhibit C hereto. 2.11 Events of Default; Default. The following shall constitute “Events of Default”: a Party fails to perform its obligations under this Agreement or the LGIA in any material respect, and such Party fails to cure such default within (i) ten (10) days (“Payment Default Cure Period”) after receipt of written notice of a payment default, or (ii) twenty (20) days (“General Default Cure Period”) after receipt of written notice of any default (other than a payment de fault), provided if the nature of the defaulted obligation or obligations other than a payment default is such that more than twenty (20) days are required, in the exercise of commercially reasonable diligence, for cure of such default, then such Co-Tenant shall not be in default under this Section 2.11 if it commence s to cure such default within twenty (20) days after receiving notice of the default and thereafter continuously pursues the same to completion with commercially reasonable diligence, such extended period not to exceed ninety (90) days, including the initial cure period. 2.12 Remedies. Subject to the last sentence of Section 5.8, in addition to all other remedies permitted by Law or under this Agreement (all of which shall be cumulative): (a) Following an Event of Default by a Co-Tenant, the non-defaulting Co-Tenant or Co-Tenants, or the Manager on behalf of itself or the other Co-Tenant(s), shall have the following remedies, exercisable only after the expiration of the Payment Default Cure Period or General Default Cure Period, as applicable: (i) In their sole and absolute discretion, to cure the default of the defaulting Co-Tenant by making or tendering the required payment or performance, and permitting the defaulting Co-Tenant’s Phase to continue to exercise its rights under the LGIA, provided that any such amounts paid by the non-defaulting Co-Tenant(s) shall be treated as a loan to the defaulting Co-Tenant, which Joan shall accrue interest until repaid in full at the Interest Rate; (ii) To demand disconnection of the defaulting Co-Tenant’s Phase in accordance with Section 2.13 hereof, provided, that (i) the Manager shall have in good faith determined that bringing an action for money damages and/or for specific performance will not provide an adequate or timely remedy for such default, (ii) the defaulting Co-Tenant’s Phase shall be permitted to reconnect promptly when and if the default is cured, and (iii) in the case of any such reconnection, any and all damage suffered and incurred by the non-defaulting Co­Tenants and the Manager have been compensated; (iii) To bring an action to specifically enforce the provisions of this Agreement; and/or (iv) To exercise any and all other rights and remedies which the nondefaulting Co-Tenant or Co-Tenants or the Manager might otherwise have at law or in equity. (b) Following an Event of Default by the Manager, the Co-Tenants shall have the following remedies, exercisable only after the expiration of the Payment Default Cure Period or General Default Cure Period, as applicable: (i) To remove the Manager for cause, as permitted by Section 3.5; (ii) In their sole discretion, cure the default of the Manager, provided any amounts paid shall be recoverable from the Manager, subject to the limitations of liability set forth in Section 3.3(c); (iii) To bring an action to specifically enforce the provisions of this Agreement; and/or (iv) To exercise any and all other rights and remedies which any one or more of the Co-Tenants might otherwise have at law or in equity. 2.13 Disconnection. The Manager shall have the power and authority to disconnect a Phase of any Co-Tenant from the Point of Interconnection (1) pursuant to Section 2.12(a)(ii) upon a Co-Tenant’s Event of Default hereunder, (2) if the Manager determines, in its good faith discretion, that disconnection is necessary in the event of an Emergency Condition or to otherwise prevent damage or injury to persons or property, including to the other Co-Tenants’ Phases, the Interconnection Facilities or the property of SDGandE or as otherwise needed to prevent or mitigate technical issues affecting the Phases, or (3) at the direction of the Participating TO or the CAISO pursuant to rights under the LGIA. Unless Manager has in its good faith determined that imminent threat of injury or death to persons, damage to property or default under the LGIA exists, Manager shall provide notice to the relevant Co-Tenant concurrently with disconnecting its Phase or as soon thereafter as is reasonably practical. In the case a default is due to the failure by a Co-Tenant to maintain its Phase Controlled Assets as required under Section 2.10, the Manager shall provide at least ten (10) days advance written notice to such Co-Tenant and any applicable Financing Party prior to disconnecting its Phase pursuant to Section 2.12(a)(ii) in order for such Co-Tenant to cure any failure. Any Phase disconnected shall be reconnected when the specific default is cured in full, the specific Emergency Condition is resolved or the Participating TO or the CAISO permits. The Manager and each of the Co-Tenants will accept substitute performance necessary to cure the default in full that is tendered by a Financing Party to cure the breach or default of such Co-Tenant. 2.14 Equitable Relief. The Parties agree that damages may be an inadequate remedy for a breach by the Manager or any other Party of its respective obligations under this Agreement, and that each Party shall be entitled to seek injunctive and other equitable relief, including specific performance, against any other Party or the Manager to prevent or eliminate such default. 2.15 Dispute Resolution. (a) Submission. In the event any Party asserts any dispute, claim or controversy that arises out of or relates to this Agreement in any manner whatsoever, whether in contract, in tort, or otherwise, and including any dispute or difference regarding the existence, validity, enforceability or termination of this Agreement (a “Dispute”), such Party shall provide the other Parties with written notice of the dispute (“Notice of Dispute”). Such Dispute shall be referred to a designated senior representative of each Party for resolution on an informal basis as promptly as practicable after receipt of the Notice of Dispute by the Parties. In the event the designated representatives are unable to resolve the Dispute through unassisted or assisted negotiations within thirty (30) days of the other Parties’ receipt of the Notice of Dispute, such Dispute may, upon mutual agreement of the Parties, be submitted to arbitration in accordance with the arbitration procedures set forth below. In the event the Parties do not agree within such thirty (30) day period to submit such claim or dispute to arbitration, each Party may exercise whatever rights and remedies it may have in equity or at Jaw consistent with the terms of this Agreement. (b) Arbitration Procedures. Any arbitration initiated under this Agreement shall be conducted before a tribunal of three (3) arbitrators appointed by the Parties. The patties to the arbitration shall appoint two arbitrators in accordance with the Arbitration Rules, and the two arbitrators so appointed shall appoint the third (and presiding arbitrator) in accordance with the Arbitration Rules within thirty (30) days after the appointment of the second arbitrator. The arbitrators shall be knowledgeable in electric utility matters, including electric transmission and bulk power issues, and shall not have any current or past substantial business or financial relationships with any party to the arbitration (except prior arbitration). The arbitrators shall provide each of the Parties an opportunity to be heard and, except as otherwise provided herein, shall conduct the arbitration in accordance with the Commercial Arbitration Rules of the American Arbitration Association (“Arbitration Rules”); provided, however, in the event of a conflict between the Arbitration Rules and the terms of this Section 2.15, the terms of this Section 2.15 shall prevail. (c) Arbitration Decisions. Unless otherwise agreed by the Parties, the arbitrators shall render a decision and shall notify the Parties in writing of such decision and the reasons therefor. The arbitrators shall be authorized only to interpret and apply the provisions of this Agreement and shall have no power to modify or change any provision of this Agreement in any manner. The decision of the arbitrators shall be final and binding upon the Parties, and judgment on the award may be entered in any court having jurisdiction. The final decision of the arbitrators must also be filed with FERC if required under the FPA or FERC decisions thereunder. (d) Costs. The prevailing Party in the dispute resolution process under this Section 2.15 shall be entitled to recover its costs and reasonable attorneys’ fees. 2.16 Effect of Force Majeure. If, because of an event of Force Majeure, any Party is unable to carry out its obligations under this Agreement, and if such Party promptly gives the other Parties written notice of such Force Majeure in detail, specifying the nature, extent and expected duration of such Force Majeure, the non-payment obligations and liabilities of the Party giving such notice and the corresponding obligations and liabilities of any other Party shall be temporarily suspended to the extent made necessary by and during the continuance of such Force Majeure; provided, that suspension of a Party’s performance hereunder due to Force Majeure shall be permitted solely to the extent that such suspension does not give rise to or cause a “Default” under the LGIA. Any disabling effects of such event of Force Majeure shall be eliminated as soon as and to the extent reasonably practicable by the Party claiming Force Majeure. 2.17 Notice of Default. Each Co-Tenant and the Manager shall promptly (and in any event within two (2) Business Days) provide written notice to the other Parties upon receiving notice of, or otherwise discovering, any default or potential default under this Agreement or the LGIA or receiving any other notice under the LGIA. 2.18 No Interference. Each Co-Tenant’s exercise of its rights under the LGIA shall not in any way interfere with the use and enjoyment by the other Co-Tenant(s) of their respective rights under the LGIA or arising under this Agreement, subject to all the terms and provisions of this Agreement. ARTICLE III MANAGER 3.1 Appointment of Manager; Manager Services and Limitations. Each Co-Tenant hereby appoints the Manager to act as its representative for all purposes under the LGIA (except as expressly stated herein), and, unless otherwise agreed by the Co-Tenants or otherwise provided herein, the Manager shall have the power to exercise and shall exercise any and all of the rights of the Interconnection Customer under the LGIA and shall coordinate, administer and manage performance of the LGIA by the Co-Tenants. The Manager shall have no interest as the Interconnection Customer, but shall serve as the Interconnection Customer’s authorized representative. (a) Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, and subject to the limitations of authority of the Manager in Section 3.1(b) below, the Manager shall have the power, without further consent or approval of the Co-Tenants: (i) To send and receive requests, demands and other notices arising under or relating to the LGIA; (ii) To employ from time to time, at the expense of the Co-Tenants, persons, firms or corporations to render services generally needed to accomplish the purposes of the Co-Tenants with respect to the LGIA (including an operations contractor as may be necessary to carry out Manager’s rights and obligations under Section 2.13); provided that if the Manager retains any party who is an Affiliate of the Manager for any of these purposes, the fees charged shall be based on the fair market value for similar services; (iii) To pay and collect amounts due in connection with the LGIA, and to maintain one or more bank accounts wherein funds received by the Manager in connection with its duties hereunder shall be maintained; (iv) To expend monies necessary for the management and administration of the LGIA in accordance with Good Utility Practice, subject to the limitations contained herein; or (v) To execute, acknowledge, and deliver any and all instruments and take such other steps as are reasonably necessary to effectuate the foregoing and as are consistent therewith. (b) The Manager shall not, without the prior, unanimous written consent of all of the Co-Tenants: (i) Create or cause to be created any lien or security interest in the LGIA, or terminate, amend or Transfer the LGIA or waive any material rights of the Co-Tenants under the LGIA or initiate or settle any dispute resolution under the LGIA; (ii) Amend or modify the terms of this Agreement, the LGIA or any other agreement to which a Co-Tenant is a party; (iii) Perform or omit to perform any act which would cause any person reasonably to believe that the Manager is authorized to bind such Co-Tenants, except as expressly provided herein, or which would cause any person reasonably to believe that the Manager is a partner of the Co-Tenant(s); (iv) Sell, assign, mortgage, encumber, convey or otherwise transfer all or any portion of any Undivided Interest; (v) Borrow funds on behalf of the Co-Tenants; (vi) Procure any insurance coverage that is less than the coverages required under Section 2.10(d); (vii) Incur expenses, on behalf of the Co-Tenants, except in accordance with this Agreement and the LGIA; or (viii) Enter into, on behalf of the Co-Tenants, any commitments, contracts or other agreements requiring expenditures in excess of Fifty Thousand Dollars ($50,000.00) or with a duration of more than one (1) year. 3.2 Communications. The Manager shall be the single point of contact between the Co-Tenants and the CAISO and SDGandE, and shall be responsible for all administrative obligations of the Interconnection Customer under the LGIA, including billing, issuing payments, providing notices and communicating with, and receiving instructions from, the CAISO and SDGandE with respect to the Phases and the LGIA. The Manager shall, promptly upon (and no later than 2 Business Days following) receipt, provide to each Co-Tenant a copy of any notices or other material communications received by it under the LGIA. The Manager’s actions and representations to the CAISO and SDGandE shall be binding upon the Interconnection Customer and each individual Co-Tenant . Each Co-Tenant waives any right to individual notice or communication from the CAISO or SDGandE, and the CAISO and SDGandE will not be obligated to act on any instructions from a Co-Tenant. 3.3 Liability and Indemnification of Manager. (a) Each Co-Tenant shall, pro rata in accordance with its Percentage Interest, defend, indemnify and hold harmless the Manager and its employees and agents, from any claim, Joss, liability or damage incurred by reason of any act performed or omitted to be performed by it in its reasonable judgment, in good faith, or in reasonable reliance on advice of the Manager’s attorneys or accountants, in connection with the LGIA or this Agreement (other than the fraud, willful misconduct or gross negligence of the Manager), including reasonable attorneys’ fees incurred by it in connection with the defense of any action based on any such alleged act or omission. The Manager shall specifically be indemnified by the Co-Tenants (pro rata in accordance with their Percentage Interests) and held harmless from any and all actions taken by the Manager in its reasonable judgment, in good faith, or in reasonable reliance on advice of the Manager’s attorneys or accountants, and shall be reimbursed by the Co-Tenants (pro rata in accordance with their Percentage Interests) for costs, which arise in connection with the LGIA or this Agreement (other than costs resulting from the fraud, willful misconduct or gross negligence of the Manager). (b) The Manager shall not be liable, responsible or accountable in damages or otherwise to any Co-Tenant for any act performed in good faith by the Manager in the discharge of its duties hereunder as the Manager or in the exercise of its powers and authority hereunder as the Manager, including, without limitation, damages arising out of the disconnection of, or the election not to disconnect, a Co-Tenant’s Phase from the Point of Interconnection, unless the acts or omissions of the Manager constitute fraud or willful misconduct or gross negligence of the Manager. (c) In no event shall the liability of Manager under the terms of this Section 3.3 or as otherwise provided hereunder (other than liability arising out of the fraud or willful misconduct or gross negligence of the Manager) exceed, in any calendar year during the term hereof, one hundred percent (100%) of the Management Fee. In no event, whether based on contract, indemnity, warranty, tort (including negligence) or otherwise, shall Manager or its respective subcontractors and suppliers be liable for special, incidental, exemplary, indirect, or consequential damages including, but not limited to, loss of profits or revenue, cost of capital, cost of purchased power, or claims of customers of Co-Tenants for such damages; provided, however, this Section 3.3 shall not be construed as a limitation or restriction on the amount or applicability of any insurance policies or coverages held by or otherwise required to be procured and obtained by the Parties under the terms of this Agreement. 3.4 Books and Records; Reporting Requirements. (a) Maintenance or Records. The Manager shall maintain books and records in sufficient detail to verify amounts due and payable hereunder for a period of not less than three (3) years after the end of the calendar month to which they relate, and all such books and records shall be available for inspection and/or copying by each Co-Tenant or its authorized representative at the cost and expense of such Co-Tenant and at reasonable times during regular business hours, upon reasonable notice to the Manager . (b) Provision of Records. In addition to fulfilling its obligations under Section 2.4, the Manager shall, from time to time or at the reasonable request of the Co-Tenants or their Financing Parties, provide reports to the Co-Tenants and their Financing Parties sufficient to keep the Co-Tenants and their Financing Parties reasonably apprised as to significant matters concerning the LGIA, the Initial Construction Costs and the LGIA Costs and Operating Expenses, and any other amounts due under the LGIA. (c) Annual Statements. The Manager shall submit to the Co-Tenants an annual statement reconciling all amounts paid by each such Co-Tenant to the Manager during the preceding twelve (12) months against such Co-Tenant’s share of all actual LGIA Costs and Operating Expenses and other amounts due from the Interconnection Customer under the LGIA during such twelve (12) month period. Upon written request given by a Co-Tenant within thirty (30) days of delivery of such annual statement, the Manager shall provide reasonable documentation of such costs and expenses incurred during the twelve (12) month period covered by such statement. If any Co-Tenant’s share of such costs and expenses exceeds the amounts paid by such Co-Tenant, then such Co-Tenant shall promptly pay the amount of such difference to the Manager. If any Co-Tenant’s share of such costs and expenses is less than the amounts paid by such Co-Tenant, then the Manager shall credit the amount of such overpayment by such Co-Tenant against future invoiced amounts from the Manager until such credit is exhausted. 3.5 Replacement of Manager. Upon the written approval of each of the Co-Tenants, the Co-Tenants may replace the Manager with any Person of their choosing; provided, however, that any Co-Tenant (acting by itself) may remove the Manager if the Manager is in material default hereunder. If a Co-Tenant (acting by itself) removes the Manager as a result of a material default hereunder, the Co-Tenants shall jointly appoint a new Manager and provide written notice to CAISO and Participating TO of the new Manager. 3.6 Management Fee. In consideration of the services provided by Manager hereunder, the Manager shall be paid an annual fee of Twelve Thousand Dollars ($12,000.00) (the “Management Fee”), payable monthly, in advance, in equal monthly installments, beginning on the date hereof and ending on the term i nation of this Agreement or the replacement of the Manager. The Management Fee shall be allocated to the Co-Tenants pro-rata in accordance with their Percentage Interests. 3.7 Discrimination. Notwithstanding any other provision herein to the contrary (other than Section 2.3 and 2.13), the Manager shall not Discriminate in providing services or otherwise performing its obligations hereunder among the Co-Tenants. As used herein, “Discriminate” means a failure by the Manager to provide services hereunder in a manner that treats alike each of the Co-Tenant s under substantially similar conditions, and for which dissimilar treatment is not otherwise justified as necessary in accordance with Good Utility Practice. 3.8 Performance. The Manager shall perform its obligations under this Agreement (a) in accordance with the terms of the LGIA, (b) in accordance with Good Utility Practice, (c) in compliance with all Applicable Laws and Regulations, including but not limited to the FPA, and all rules, regulations, and orders issued by the FERC pursuant to the FPA, (d) in compliance with the CAISO Tariff, including the rules, protocols, procedures and standards attached thereto, as the same may be amended from time to time and approved by FERC, (c) in compliance with the rules, protocols, procedures and standards of NERC, and (f) in accordance with the LGIA. 3.9 Access Rights. Each Co-Tenant shall, following receipt of reasonable notice provided by Manager, provide the Manager with reasonable access to its Phase in order for Manager to carry out its rights and obligations hereunder. Manager shall carry out its rights and obligations in a manner consistent with each Co-Tenant’s safety protocols and procedures as notified in writing to Manager by each Co-Tenant from time to time. 3.10 Subcontracting. Manager may delegate or subcontract the performance of its obligations under this Agreement; provided that no subcontracting of services by Manager to a subcontractor shall (i) relieve Manager of any of its duties, responsibilities, obligations or liabilities hereunder, (ii) relieve Manager of its responsibility for the completion of performance of any services rendered by any such subcontractor or (iii) create any relationship between the Co-Tenants, on the one hand, and any subcontractor, on the other. In addition, Manager shall cause each of its subcontractors to comply with the requirements of this Agreement that are applicable to such subcontractor’s work as if such subcontractor were Manager hereunder. ARTICLE IV TRANSFERABILITY 4.1 General Restriction and Obligation. Each Party may Transfer its rights and obligations under this Agreement to any another Person solely to the extent such Party is permitted under the LGIA to Transfer, and does in fact Transfer, its rights and obligations under the LGIA to such other Person, provided that no Co-Tenant may assign its interests as tenant-in­ common in the Interconnection Customer’s Interconnection Facilities, and other rights and obligations under the LGIA, independently of its interest in the Project. In the event a Party Transfers its rights and obligations under the LGIA to another Person, such Party shall promptly (and in no event later than five (5) Business Days following such transfer) transfer its rights and obligations under this Agreement to such Transferee. 4.2 Co-Tenant’ s Right to Encumber. Notwithstanding anything in Section 4.1 to the contrary, each Co-Tenant may, at any time and from time to time during the term of this Agreement, encumber, mortgage or hypothecate to any Financing Party by deed of trust or mortgage or other security instrument all or part of such Co-Tenant’s interest under this Agreement and the other documents entered into in connection with this Agreement, including, without limitation, the LGIA, without the consent of the other Co-Tenants, provided that the foregoing may not increase the number of Co-Tenants. 4.3 Certain Rights of Financing Party. Should a Co-Tenant incur any encumbrance in accordance with Section 4.2 of this Agreement, and should the Parties receive notice thereof pursuant to Section 5.1 hereof, the Parties hereby expressly stipulate and agree as follows: (a) Modification of Agreement. They will not materially modify this Agreement or voluntarily cancel this Agreement without the written consent of the Financing Party, which consent may not be unreasonably withheld or delayed. (b) Performance by Financing Party. The Financing Party shall have the right to do any act or thing required of the encumbering Co-Tenant under this Agreement, and any such act or thing performed by the Financing Party shall be as effective to prevent an applicable default under this Agreement and/or a forfeiture of any of such Co-Tenant’s applicable rights under this Agreement as if do ne by the Co-Tenant itself. (c) Notice to Financing Party. If Manager issues or receives any notices regarding potential or actual defaults as described in Section 2.17 herein, the Manager, on behalf of the Co-Tenant s, shall promptly deliver a copy of such notice to all Financing Parties of which it has received notice. (d) Consents to Assignment. Each Co-Tenant and the Manager hereby agrees that it shall, no later than five (5) business days after a request by a Co-Tenant (or its Financing Party), execute such consents or estoppel certificates as are reasonably requested by the requesting Co-Tenant or its Financing Party. 4.4 FERC Approval. Notwithstanding anything in Section 4.1 or 4.2 to the contrary, no Transfer of a Co-Tenant’s interests in this Agreement shall be effective unless and until the Transferring Co-Tenant or the Manager has obtained any necessary prior approvals from the FERC to effectuate any changes to this Agreement to reflect such Transfer and the change in the Parties to this Agreement. ARTICLE V MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 5.1 Notices. Any notice, demand, or communication required or permitted to be given by any provision of this Agreement shall be deemed to have been sufficiently given or served for all purposes if delivered personally or by telecopy to the Party or to an executive officer of the Party to whom the same is directed or, if sent by registered or certified mail, postage and charges prepaid, addressed to the Party’s address, as appropriate, which is set forth below or to such other address as a Party shall advise the other Parties from time to time in writing. If to JVS-1: Imperial Valley Solar 1, LLC c/o AES Solar Power, LLC 430l N. Fairfax Drive, Suite 360 Arlington, VA 22203 Attention: Ms. Rebecca Cranna Facsimile No.: (703) 682-1157 E-mail: becky.cranna@aes.com If to IVS-2: Imperial Valley Sola r 2, LLC c/o AES Solar Power, LLC 4301 N. Fairfax Drive, Suite 360 Arlington, VA 22203 Attention: Ms. Rebecca Cranna Facsimile No.: (703) 682-1157 E-mail: becky.cranna@ aes.com If to IVS-3: Imperial Valley Solar 3, LLC c/o AES Solar Power, LLC 4301 N. Fairfax Drive, Suite 360 Arlington, VA 22203 Attention: Ms. Rebecca Cranna Facsimile No.: (703) 682-1157 E-mail: becky.cranna@aes. com lf to IVS-4: Imperial Valley Solar 4, LLC c/o AES Solar Power, LLC 4301 N. Fairfax Drive, Suite 360 Arlington, VA 22203 Attention: Ms. Rebecca Cranna Facsimile No.: (703) 682-1157 E-mail: becky.cranna@aes.com If to Manager: Imperial Valley Solar, LLC c/o AES Solar Power, LLC 4301 N. Fairfax Drive, Suite 360 Arlington, VA 22203 Attention: Ms. Rebecca Cranna Facsimile No.: (703) 682-1157 E-mail: becky.cranna@aes.com 5.2 Choice of Law. This Agreement shall in all respects be governed by and construed and enforced in accordance with the internal laws of the State of California, without regard to its choice of law provisions. 5.3 Entire Agreement. This Agreement sets forth the complete understanding of the Parties hereto with respect to the subject matter hereof and supersedes all prior discussions, agreements, and undertakings relating to the subject matter hereof. 5.4 Interpretation. All personal pronouns used in this Agreement, whether used in the masculine, feminine or neuter gender, shall include all other genders; the singular shall include the plural; and the plural shall include the singular. Titles of articles and sections in this Agreement are for convenience only and neither limit nor amplify the provisions of this Agreement. All references in this Agreement to articles, sect ions, subsect ions or paragraphs shall refer to articles, sections, subsections and paragraphs of this Agreement, unless specific reference is made to the articles, sections or other subdivisions of another document or instrument. The word “including” shall mean “ including without limitation”. This Agreement shall not be interpreted in favor of any Party by virtue of said Party not having prepared this Agreement. The unenforceability, invalidity, or illegality of any provision of this Agreement shall not affect or impair the continuing enforceability or validity of any other part, all of which shall survive and be valid and enforceable. 5.5 Waiver. No consent or waiver, express or implied by any Party hereto, to or of any breach or default by the other in the performance by the other of its obligations hereunder shall be deemed or construed to be a consent or waiver to or of any other breach or default in the performance by such other Party of the same or any other obligations of such Party hereunder. Failure on the part of any Party hereto to complain of any act or failure to act of any other Party, or to declare such other Party in default, irrespective of how long such failure continues, shall not constitute a waiver of such Party of its rights hereunder. 5.6 Third Party Beneficiaries. This Agreement and the terms and provisions hereof are solely and exclusively for the benefit of the Parties hereto. No third party may rely on any of the provisions herein contained or lay claim to any of the rights of the Parties hereto. 5.7 Counterparts; Facsimile Signatures. This Agreement may be executed in counterparts each of which when so executed and delivered shall be deemed to be an original and all of which together shall constitute one instrument. Signatures delivered by facsimile, email or other electronic means shall be binding upon the Parties hereto with the same force and effect as original signatures. 5.8 Amendments; Term. Except as specifically provided in this Agreement, this Agreement shall not be amended except by the written agreement of the Manager and all the other Parties (and any amendment to this Agreement shall also be subject to review and approval by the CAISO and SDGandE, which consent shall not be withheld unreasonably); provided, however, that Manager’s consent is not required for any amendment hereof so long as its rights and obligations are not adversely affected thereby. In addition, no Party may amend the LGIA except by the written consent of all the Co-Tenants. The Manager shall provide to each of the Co-Tenants a copy of the final amendment to the LGIA permitted pursuant to this Section 5.8. This Agreement shall be in effect for so long as the LGIA is in effect. 5.9 Acknowledgement and Further Assurances. Each Party acknowledges and represents to the other Parties that this Agreement is consistent with all of the requirements set forth in the LGIA. Upon the reasonable request of any Party at any time after the Effective Date, the other Parties shall forthwith execute and deliver such further instruments of assignment, transfer, conveyance, endorsement, direction or authorization and other documents as the requesting Party or its or their counsel may reasonably request in order to effectuate the purposes of this Agreement. Each Party agrees to reasonably cooperate with the other Parties in assisting it to comply with the terms of this Agreement, including, but not limited to, assistance in obtaining consents, waivers, authorizations, waivers, authorizations, orders and/or approvals of third parties. 5.10 WAIVER OF RIGHT TO PARTITION. THE CO TENANTS EACH ACKNOWLEDGE AND AGREE THAT IT WOULD BE PREJUDICIAL TO THE INTERESTS OF THE CO-TENANTS UNDER THIS AGREEMENT IF ANY CO-TENANT WERE TO SEEK PARTITION OR ANY OTHER TYPE OF DIVISION OF THE LGIA, OR FILE AN ACTION FOR SUCH PARTITION OR DIVISION. THEREFORE, IN CONSIDERATION OF SUCH FACT AND FOR OTHER GOOD AND VALUABLE CONSIDERATION, EACH OF THE CO-TENANTS HEREBY WAIVES AND RELINQUISHES ANY AND ALL RIGHTS THAT IT MAY HAVE TO SEEK A PARTITION OR ANY OTHER TYPE OF DIVISION OF THE LGIA. 5.11 Consequential Damages. In no event shall any Party be liable under any provision of this Agreement for any losses, damages, costs, or expenses for any special, indirect, incidental, consequential, or punitive damages, including but not limited to loss of profit or revenue, loss of the use of equipment, cost of capital, cost of temporary equipment, or services, whether based in whole or in part in contract, in tort, including negligence, strict liability, or any other theory of liability. 5.12 Co-Tenant Representative. On or promptly after the Effective Date, each Co­Tenant shall by written notice to the other Co-Tenants designate an individual representative (the “Co-Tenant Representative”) whose instructions, requests, and decisions will be binding upon such Co-Tenant in all matters concerning this Agreement, except that the Co-Tenant’s Representative shall not have the authority to amend this Agreement. Each Co-Tenant shall have the right to change such Co-Tenant’s Representative at any time and from time to time by written notice to the other Co-Tenants and Manager. 5.13 Manager Representative. On or promptly after the Effective Date, the Manager shall, by written notice to the other Parties, designate an individual representative (the “Manager Representative”) whose instructions, requests, and decisions will be binding upon the Manager in all matters concerning this Agreement, except that the Manager Representative shall not have the authority to amend this Agreement. The Manager shall have the right to change the Manager Representative at any time and from time to time by written notice to the other Parties. [Signature Page Follows] IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the Parties hereto have executed this Agreement as of the date first written above. Imperial Valley Solar 1, LLC, a Delaware limited liability company By: Name: Title: Date: Imperial Valley Solar 2, LLC, a Delaware limited liability company By: Name: Title: Date: Imperial Valley Solar 3, LLC, a Delaware limited liability company By: Name: Title: Date: Imperial Valley Solar 4, LLC, a Delaware limited liability company By: Name: Title: Date: Imperial Valley Solar, LLC, a Delaware limited liability company By: Name: Title: Date: [SIGNATURE PAGE TO LGIA CO-TENANCY AGREEMENT] EXHIBIT A Maximum Capacities Phase Capacity Phase 1 200 MW Phase 2 150 MW Phase 3 150 MW Phase 4 100 MW Total (All Phases) 600 MW EXHIBIT B Minimum Insurance Requirements for Co-Tenants Each Co-Tenant shall maintain or cause to be maintained the insurance required as described in the LGIA (including Section 18.3 of the LGIA), and as further described herein, with insurance companies licensed to write such insurance in the State of California and rated A-7 or better, by Best’s Insurance Guide and Key Ratings (or an equivalent rating by another nationally recognized insurance rating agency of similar standing if Best’s Insurance Guide and Key Ratings shall no longer be published) or other insurance companies of recognized responsibility reasonably satisfactory to the other Co-Tenants and Manager. In the event of inconsistencies between the requirements under the LGIA and the requirements under this Exhibit B, the requirements under the LGIA shall prevail. 1. Comprehensive or Commercial General Liability Insurance. From and after the Effective Date, each Co-Tenant shall maintain or cause to be maintained comprehensive or commercial general liability insurance on an “occurrence” bas is, including coverage for premises/ operations, explosion, collapse and underground hazards, products/completed operations, broad form property damage, blanket contractual liability for both oral and written contracts, independent contractor’s and personal injury, for such Co-Tenant and for contractors, with primary coverage limits of not less than $1,000,000 for injuries or death to one or more persons or damage to property resulting from any one occurrence and a $2,000,000 aggregate limit. Deductibles in excess of $250,000 shall be subject to approval by Manager and the other Co-Tenant . The comprehensive or commercial general liability policy shall also include a severability of interest clause and cross liability if the policy has multiple named insureds. 2. Automobile Liability Insurance. From and after the Effective Date, each Co-Tenant shall maintain or cause to be maintained automobile liability insurance, to the extent exposure exists, including coverage for owned, non-owned and hired automobiles for both bodily injury and property damage and containing appropriate no-fault insurance provisions or other endorsements in accordance with state legal requirements, with limits of not less than $1,000,000 per accident with respect to bodily injury, property damage or death. 3. All-Risk Property Insurance. From and after the commencement of construction by a Co­ Tenant, such Co-Tenant shall maintain or cause to be maintained “all risk” property insurance coverage in the full amount and coverage terms required under its financing agreements. The payment of the deductible for a Co-Tenant’s “All Risk” insurance shall be the responsibility of such Co-Tenant, unless the loss covered by such insurance is caused by the gross negligence or willful misconduct of another Co-Tenant or Manager, in which case, the deductible shall be paid by such Co-Tenant or Manager, as the case may be, subject to the limitations of Sections 3.3(c) and 5.11 of the Agreement. The Co-Tenants shall also maintain or cause to be maintained with respect to its project assets business interruption insurance on an “all risk” basis, in an amount and coverage terms required under its financing agreements. 4. Umbrella Excess Liability Insurance. Each Co-Tenant shall maintain or cause to be maintained Umbrella Excess Liability Insurance of not less than $9,000,000. Such coverages shall be on a per occurrence basis or Aegis claims made and over and above coverage provided by the policies described in Sections 1 and 2 above. The umbrella and/or excess policies shall not contain endorsements which restrict coverages as set forth in Sections 1 and 2 above, and which are provided in the underlying policies. If the policy or policies provided under this Section 4 contain(s) aggregate limits, and such limits are diminished by any incident, occurrence, claim, settlement or judgment against such insurance which has caused the carrier to establish a reserve that exceeds 50% of the $9,000,000 limit, each Co-Tenant shall take immediate steps to restore such aggregate limits or shall provide other equivalent insurance protection for such aggregate limits. 5. Aircraft Liability Insurance. The Co-Tenants shall maintain or cause to be maintained aircraft liability, to the extent exposure exists, for the use of any owned, non-owned or hired aircraft used in the construction or operation of the Project with limits of not less than $10,000,000. 6. Other Insurance. Each Co-Tenant shall maintain or cause to be maintained such other or additional insurance (as to risks cove red, policy amounts, policy provisions or otherwise) as, under Good Utility Practice, are from time to time insured against for property and facilities similar in nature, use and location to the its project assets. 7. General Terms. Policies issued pursuant hereto shall contain the following or equivalent wording unless waived in writing by Manager: 7.1 Errors and Omissions – It is hereby understood and agreed that the coverages afforded by this policy to one insured shall not be invalidated or affected by any unintentional errors, omissions, or in any information required to be reported by another insured. 7.2 Notice of Injurious Exposure to Conditions (Third-Party Policies Only) – It is agreed that failure of any agent, servant, or employee of the insured other than the owner, partner of any partnership, or an officer of the insured to notify the company of any occurrence of which he has knowledge shall not invalidate the insurance afforded by this policy as respects the named insured. 7.3 Knowledge of Injurious Exposure to Conditions (Third-Party Policies Only) – It is hereby understood and agreed that knowledge of an occurrence by the agent, servant, or employee of the insured shall not in itself constitute knowledge by the insured, unless an executive officer of the insured’s corporation or the owner or a partner of any partnership insured shall have received such notice from its or their agent, servant, or employee. 7.4 All insurance coverage shall be on a “no coinsurance or self-insurance/ replacement cost” basis and in such form (including the form of the Joss payable clauses) as shall be acceptable to the other Co-Tenants and Manager (which acceptance shall not be unreasonably withheld). Copies of policies shall be submitted to the other Co-Tenants and Manager upon request. 8. Interest of Manager. All policies wherein Manager has an insurable interest shall insure the interests of Manager and shall name Manager as additional insured to the extent of each Co­ Tenant’s indemnity obligations contained herein, unless Manager is named as an insured under the policy. Each policy shall expressly provide that all provisions thereof, except the limits of liability (which shall be applicable to all insureds as a group) and liability for premiums (which shall be solely a liability of each Co-Tenant) shall operate in the same manner as if there were a separate policy covering each such insured. Each policy shall waive subrogation against Manager and shall waive any right of the insurers to any setoff or counterclaim or any other deduction, whether by attachment or otherwise, in respect of any liability of the Co-Tenants or Manager. 9. Proof of Loss. Each Co-Tenant understands and agrees that in the event that such Co­Tenant, fails to respond in a timely and appropriate manner (as reasonably determined by Manager) to take any steps necessary or reasonably requested by Manager to collect from any insurers for any loss of Manager covered by any insurance required to be maintained by this Exhibit B, Manager shall have the right to make all proofs of loss, adjust all claims and/or receive all or any part of the proceeds of the foregoing insurance policies to the extent of any such loss of Manager covered by such insurance, either in its own name or the name of Manager or each such Co-Tenant, as the case may be. The rights provided to Manager in this section shall only be applicable to the extent that such rights to make proofs of loss, adjust claims or receive directly from insurers all or any part of insurance proceeds is not in conflict with any financing documents between each Co-Tenant and any applicable financing parties, as determined by the Co-Tenant in consultation with its financing parties. 10. Claims Made Policies. In the event that any policy is written on a “claims-made” basis and such policy is not renewed or the retroactive date of such policy is to be changed, each Co­Tenant shall obtain for each such policy or policies the broadest basic and supplemental extended reporting period coverage or “tail” reasonably available in the commercial insurance market for each such policy or policies and shall provide Manager with proof that such basic and supplemental extended reporting period coverage or “tail” has been obtained. 11. Notification. The applicable Co-Tenant shall notify Manager of any claim made under any insurance required to be provided hereunder and shall keep Manager timely apprised of insurance claim proceedings. Manager understand and agree that all amounts and proceeds (including instruments) in respect of the proceeds of any insurance policy required to be maintained by each Co-Tenant hereunder shall be applied as provided in any financing documents between such Co-Tenant and any applicable financing parties. 12. Availability of Insurance on Commercially Reasonable Terms. In the event any insurance (including the limits or deductibles thereof) required hereunder to be maintained, other than insurance required by law to be maintained, shall not be available and commercially reasonable terms in the commercial insurance market, Manager shall not unreasonably withhold its agreement to waive such requirement to the extent the maintenance thereof is not so available; provided, however, that (i) the applicable Co Tenant shall first request any such waiver in writing, which request shall be accompanied by written reports prepared by such Co-Tenant certifying that such insurance is not available on commercially reasonable terms in the commercial insurance market for electric generating plants of similar type and capacity (and, in any case where the required amount is not so available, certifying as to the maximum amount which is so available) and explaining in detail the basis for such conclusions and the form and substance of such reports to be reasonably acceptable to Manager; (ii) at any time after the granting of any such waiver, Manager may request, and the applicable Co-Tenant shall furnish to Manager within fifteen (15) days after such request, supplemental reports reasonably acceptable to Manager updating the prior reports and reaffirming such conclusion; (iii) any such waiver shall be effective only so long as such insurance shall not be available on commercially reasonable terms in the commercial insurance market, it being understood that the failure of a Co-Tenant to timely furnish any such supplemental report shall be conclusive evidence that such waiver is no longer effective because such condition no longer exists; and (iv) such Co-Tenant shall indemnify and hold harmless Manager and the other Co-Tenants for any losses sustained by them as a result of coverages required under this Agreement that have not been obtained by such Co-Tenant as a result of this section. For purposes of this Agreement, if the aggregate premiums to be paid for the renewal of all of the insurance required to be provided hereunder, when taken as a whole, are no more than the greater of (i) 110% of the amount of the premiums paid for the prior renewal or (ii) the amount budgeted for such renewal at any time in the immediately preceding five (5) years, such insurance shall be deemed to be commercially reasonable. 13. Conflict with a Co-Tenant’s Financing Arrangements. In the event that compliance with any insurance (including the limits or deductibles thereof) required hereunder is in conflict with a Co-Tenant’s obligations under any financing documents between the such Co-Tenant and any applicable Financing Parties, the provisions of such financing documents shall prevail so as to ensure that the such Co-Tenant is not in default of such requirements, as determined by the Co-Tenants in consultation with Financing Parties; provided that, in any event, such Co­ Tenant shall indemnify and hold harmless Manager and the other Co-Tenants for any losses sustained by them as a result of coverages required under this Agreement that have not been obtained by such Co-Tenant as a result of this section. 14. Indemnity. In the event that any Co-Tenant fails to comply with any insurance (including the limits or deductibles thereof) required hereunder, such Co-Tenant shall indemnify and hold harmless Manager and the other Co-Tenants for any losses sustained by them as a result of such failure. EXHIBIT C Minimum Insurance Requirements for Manager On and following the Effective Date, Manager shall obtain and maintain the insurance required as described herein. Insurance coverages shall be maintained with insurance companies licensed to write such insurance in the State of California and rated “A- 7” or better, by Best’s Insurance Guide and Key Ratings (or an equivalent rating by another nationally recognized insurance rating agency of similar standing if Best’s Insurance Guide and Key Ratings shall no longer be published) or other insurance companies of recognized responsibility satisfactory to the Co-Tenants and shall include: 1. Commercial General Liability Insurance. Manager shall maintain or cause to be maintained commercial general liability insurance on an “occurrence” basis, including coverage for premises/operations, explosion, collapse and underground hazards, products/completed operations, broad form property damage, blanket contractual liability for written contracts, independent Manager’s and personal injury, with primary coverage limits of no less than $1,000, 000 for injuries or death to one or more persons or damage to property resulting from any one occurrence and a $2,000,000 minimum aggregate limit. 1.1 Cross-liability or Severability of Interest Clause. The commercial general liability policy shall also include a cross-liability or severability of interest clause. 1.2 Subcontractor / Verification of Coverage. Manager shall require, subject to Section 1.6 of this Exhibit C, all of its subcontractors to obtain, maintain and keep in force during the time during which they are involved in performance of their work coverage in accordance with the insurance requirements set forth in this Exhibit C. Manager shall deliver to the Co-Tenants certificates of insurance evidencing such coverage. Work performed by Manager’s subcontractors shall not commence until a certificate of insurance has been delivered verifying coverages required hereunder to be in place and naming Manager and the Co-Tenants as insureds or additional insureds, as appropriate. 1.3 Equipment, Supplies and Materials. Manager or its subcontractors shall bear the sole risk for all equipment, supplies and materials belonging to Manager or to any such subcontractor, as applicable. 1.4 Notice. Each such policy shall provide that if any premium or installment is not paid when due, or if such insurance is to be canceled, terminated or adversely materially changed for any reason whatsoever, the insurers (or their representatives) will promptly notify Manager, and any such cancellation, termination or change shall not be effective until forty-five (45) days (ten (10) days with regard to nonpayment) after receipt of such notice by Manager, other than in respect of policies covering war and kindred risks, and that appropriate certification shall be made to Manager by each insurer with respect thereto. 1.5 Deductibles. Deductibles in excess of $250,000 shall be subject to review and approval by the Co-Tenants. 1.6 Subcontractors. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary above, the minimum combined general liability policy limit required of subcontractors shall be $1,000,000 (One Million Dollars) and subcontractors shall not be required to maintain Umbrella Excess Liability Coverage as described in Section 4 of this Exhibit C except to meet, if necessary, such $1,000,000 requirement. 2. Automobile Liability Insurance. To the extent exposure exists, Manager shall maintain or cause to be maintained automobile liability insurance, including coverage for owned, non-owned and hired automobiles for both bodily injury and property damage and containing appropriate no-fault insurance provisions or other endorsements in accordance with state legal requirements, with limits of not less than $ 1,000,000 per accident with respect to bodily injury, property damage or death. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this Section 2, the minimum combined automobile liability policy limit required of subcontractors shall be $1,000,000. 3. Workers Compensation. Manager shall maintain or cause to be maintained workers compensation insurance, disability benefits insurance and such other forms of insurance which Manager is required by law to provide for employees used in connection with the Project, providing statutory benefits and other states’ endorsement and USLandH Act coverage (if any exposure exists), covering loss resulting from injury, sickness, disability or death of the employees of Manager. Manager shall require that all contractors and subcontractors maintain all forms or types of insurance with respect to their employees as are required by law with Employer Liability limits of not less than $1,000,000 per accident, $1,000,000 for disease, and $1,000,000 for each employee. 4. Umbrella Excess Liability Insurance. Manager shall maintain or cause to be maintained umbrella excess liability insurance of not less than $5,000,000. Such coverages shall be on a per occurrence basis or AEGIS claims made and over and above coverage provided by the policies described in Sections 1, 2 and 3 of this Exhibit C. The umbrella and/or excess policies shall not contain endorsements which restrict coverages as set forth in this Section 4 and which are provided in the underlying policies . 5. Additional Insureds. The Co-Tenants and their officers, directors, employees, agents or affiliates shall be designated as additional insureds on the foregoing policies, with the exception of workers compensation policies. 6. Waiver of Subrogation. All policies required to be provided by Manager hereunder shall (either expressly or by applicable Law or insurance industry standard) waive subrogation against the Co-Tenants and their officers, directors, employees, agents or affiliates and shall waive any right of the insurers to any setoff or counterclaim or any other deduction, whether by attachment or otherwise, in respect of any liability of the Co-Tenants or Manager provided that the Co-Tenants’ property policies to be provided pursuant to Exhibit B shall be primary with respect to any insurable property loss to their owned assets, including losses resulting from the negligence or acts or omissions of Manager (subject to Manager’s responsibility for all or a portion of the property policy deductible and the limitations of Sections 3.3(c) and 5.11 of this Agreement) .
record_data.filing_title: Imperial Valley Solar 3, LLC Co Tenancy Agreement
